data.title: This Week in History: 1937 A Hollywood queen meets a grisly end
data.meta_description: Marie Prevost was one of the brightest stars in Hollywood in the 1920s.
data.text:
Article content

Marie Prevost was one of the brightest stars in Hollywood in the 1920s.

“With dark brown hair and blue eyes, as well as a piquant and provocative manner, Marie was one of the most attractive and individual of the (Mack Sennett) bathing girls,” wrote Edwin Schallert of the Los Angeles Times.

“When at her height and especially under Ernst Lubitsch’s direction, Miss Prevost evidenced a very brilliant sense of comedy. She knew well the silent screen technique as a result of her Mack Sennett experience.”

Article content

She has 120 film credits on her imdb database, beginning with the 1915 short His Father’s Footsteps. Her hits included The Marriage Circle (1924), Up in Mabel’s Room (1926) and Getting Gertie’s Garter (1927).

But she was a silent screen star. When the talkies came in, and she started to age, the good roles grew scarce. And on Jan. 25, 1937, Vancouverites opened their papers to the startling news that Marie Prevost was dead at 38.

“Death in a small Hollywood apartment ended Marie Prevost’s futile fight to retrieve her faded screen glory,” said an Associated Press story in the Province. “Dr. Frank N. Webb, assistant county autopsy surgeon, said a post-mortem examination indicated acute alcoholism as the cause of death.”

The Los Angeles Times ran the story on the front page of its Sunday edition. And it was tragic.

“Apparently dead two days, her body was found clothed and face down on a folding bed. Whining at the bedside was her pet dachshund, Maxie, and teeth marks on the actress’s body indicated the animal had tugged at his mistress in an attempt to arouse her.”

As time passed, her sad and lonely death was all but forgotten. But it was resurrected in 1959, when Kenneth Anger released his infamous book Hollywood Babylon.

Article content

Advertisement 3

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Anger dished out Hollywood’s most sordid scandals in a nasty tabloid style, and Marie was one of his subjects.

“Her romantic looks didn’t fit her Bronx honk, and blonde Marie tried to drown her heartbreak in bourbon,” Anger wrote.

“Marie dragged on until 1937, when her half-eaten corpse was discovered in her seedy apartment on Calhuenga Boulevard. Her dachshund had survived by making mincemeat of his mistress.”

His comments were related over top of a grisly photo of the dead movie star lying face down in her bed. The cutline for the photo was two words: “Doggie’s dinner.”

This piqued the interest of British new wave music legend Nick Lowe, who was inspired to write a song about Marie for his 1977 EP, Bowi. It’s a black humour masterpiece with a great melody and an unforgettable chorus, “She was a winner that became a doggie’s dinner.”

Some silent movie fans question Anger’s account of Maxie snacking on Marie. Anger never seemed to let the facts get in the way of a good story — Marie wasn’t blonde, or from New York, and didn’t live on Calhuenga Boulevard. But there is no doubt Marie Prevost had a tragic life.

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

She was born Marie Bickford Dunn in Sarnia, Ont., on Nov. 8, 1898. Her father was a Grand Trunk Railway conductor who died in 1904 when he was one of six men asphyxiated by fumes from a steam locomotive in a railway tunnel in Sarnia.

Marie’s mother married Frank Prevost, and the family moved around the U.S. until settling in Los Angeles. Marie was discovered when she was visiting a set and was mistaken for an actress and put into a scene. Mack Sennett spotted Marie’s natural comic ability, and signed her up for $15 a week.

Being beautiful helped, of course. In 1923, a Los Angeles Times writer called her the “delectable Marie Prevost,” a woman with a “form divine.”

In 1924, her marriage to fellow star Kenneth Harlan was touted as “the romance of the Hollywood year.” But “Hollywood’s perfect marital team” separated in 1927 and divorced two years later.

Marie was quite wealthy at one point, with a big mansion in Beverly Hills. But she lost her fortune in the 1929 stock market crash and ensuing Great Depression. When she died, she left an estate of only $300.

jmackie@postmedia.com
